Thanks, @siju-samuel for the contribution and sorry for the delayed review. By looking into the current PR I think we can split it into two logical parts.

The current workflow of debugger works by running debug-runtime collect all the data we need, and then invoke a visualizer to step through the collected result.

So logically, we can draw a picture like

```tvm.contrib.debugger.DebugGraphRuntime -> tvm.contrib.debugger.DebugResult(currently GraphModuleDebugDumpDatum) -> UX```

Let us change this PR to only contain ```tvm.contrib.debugger.DebugGraphRuntime -> tvm.contrib.debugger.DebugResult(currently GraphModuleDebugDumpDatum) ``` and document the debug result exchange format clearly.

We can bring this in first. Once this PR get merged. The users can readily try out the debugger feature if we wrap the curse visualizer as a separate python package that you maintain. I would recommend we collect feedbacks from users and improves the curses UX, before we stablize and merge it back to master.

The tensorboard support can also be done in concurrent PRs. I recommend this path because this will force us think carefully about this separation of UX and data logging, and also ensures the high quality components, as @yzhliu and I can review the data logging components but less familar with the UX part
@srkreddy1238 @PariksheetPinjari909 can you also please help review?

@kazum I have made some followup comments. One general feeling I have in the current change is that the template has been abused a bit.

Actually, we could logically divide things into

```c++
common base, no template, common logics:

OpenCLWorkspace,
OpenCLModuleNode,
OpenCLThreadEntry


SDAccelWorkspace : OpenCLWorkspace
SDAccelModuleNode: OpenCLModuleNode
```

The key problem we might face is that some cases we might need to get back to the Global singleton reference. This can likely be resolved by adding a virtual function(GetGlobalWorkspace) and do subclassing

The second comment is that we want to optionally build sdaccel as a module, without build both when opencl is enabled. This is to minimize the tvm runtime size which could be important for mobile devices.


@tqchen seems good to me 👍

The values of the result should be the same, but the layout can be different. Take Winograd F(2x2, 3x3) , for example. The straightforward layout of filter transform for GPU backend is (4, 4, in_channel, num_filter), while for cpu backend, I found it better to be in (in_channel/8, num_filter/8, 4, 4, 8, 8). 

Of course, the layout also differs for Winograd F(4x4, 3x3).

This PR introduces VTA, a custom deep learning accelerator back-end to VTA.

Approved!

@masahi 
I see winograd is about the scheduling the computation.

To my knowledge the precompute pass returns a sub graph out of the main graph which is independent or graph inputs and can be precomputed. Some set of nodes here becomes params (and some params may get dropped.).

Precompute pass doesn't know any thing about target. Not sure how this will have an impact with layout.

I think I am missing some thing here ...!

If you are not familiar with winograd convolution, you can read about it in [this cool paper](http://openaccess.thecvf.com/content_cvpr_2016/papers/Lavin_Fast_Algorithms_for_CVPR_2016_paper.pdf).

The precompute pass returns a new graph (not a subgraph) and parameters. When you invoke nnvm compiler like this,

 ```
 graph, lib, params = nnvm.compiler.build(
                net, args.target, shape={"data": data_shape}, params=params)
```
the returned params can be different from the passed params. For example, the layout of filter weight can change from OIHW to OIHW8i8o. This is what 'AlterOpLayout' pass will do for x86 target when opt_level is 3. This mechanism can be used for precomputing winograd filter transform as well. 

By making precompute pass target-aware, we can modify how things get precomputed, depending on targets.

@masahi 
Thanks for the information :+1: .
@tqchen @tmoreau89 @comaniac Can you review this PR?

I dont't  think we should change precompute pass. 
To precompute winograd filter transformation,  we can make two nnvm symbols (one for kernel transformation, one for the remaining computation), and register alter_op_layout to split the original conv2d symbol to these two symbols.
Since alter_op_layout is target aware, we can choose the correct symbols in alter_op_layout function.

Yes, I made two nnvm symbols, one for kernel transform and another for actual convolution, just like you said. And I have two different kernel transforms for cpu and gpu backend.

The problem is,  precompute_prune function always uses llvm backend [here](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/nnvm/python/nnvm/compiler/build_module.py#L341), even if I want to compile for CUDA. So during precompute phase, cpu kernel transform is chosen, even though I want to run the kernel transform registered for cuda backend.

Let me know if it is still not clear. I also want to know if there is an alternative solution.

@avlechen I tried VGG16, it works fine with cuda target. Can you update tvm to the latest?

@comaniac Thanks for your comments.  This PR generates one bitstream with multiple kernels, so there is no overhead of reconfiguration.  However, as you said, there is plenty of room for performance improvement like how to fuse computation into one kernel as far as possible or how to transfer data between multiple kernels.  I think of addressing these in future PRs. :)
cc @nhynes @yidawang

My understanding is the same as @merrymercy. We define layout related stuffs, such as kernel pre-packing in alter_op_layout, which is target specific. Then in precompute the pre-pack is executed. llvm should be enough, since the execution patten has been already well defined in alter_op_layout and result is the same.
Sorry I missed looking the `append` after you got the `xo` for each kernel. It does generate one bit-stream for all kernels.

'alter_op_layout' is implemented as target specific, for sure. But in the current implementation, even if I register CUDA specific precompute pass to 'alter_op_layout',  it will never be chosen during precompute phase. This is because precompute pass always targets the llvm backend. 

The point is that the result of alter_op_layout is not 'identical' among different backends, in that desired layout can be different.  Let me give a concrete example.

 In Mali backend's winograd, the kernel transform declared [here](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/topi/python/topi/mali/conv2d.py#L577) is in layout (alpha, alpha, K // bna, C, bna). We can move the kernel transform to precompute phase, but if later someone implements winograd convolution without kernel transform for other backends (which I did for cpu and cuda), all other backends need to adapt the same kernel transform layout, because it is not possible to use different kernel transform for different targets.

Looks fine to me.
We did add some changes to the RPC Android App for robustness when RPC crashes and this will add some CPU overhead as there is a watchdog that polls the RPC service every 5s. Another change that might affect performance is that the RPC runtime has been moved into a Service (I don't know if Android has a different CPU priority for Services vs Activities).
Note that if you are referring to the deploy Android app then that should remain unaffected.

https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/topi/python/topi/x86/conv2d.py#L157-L162 This is how we do kernel prepack for avx-512. Kernel prepack is done in pre-compute pass and we don't need to specify "llvm -mcpu=skylake-avx512" for pre-compute. This method should be able to apply to other targets. Is there anything missing for your use case?

Yes, I am fairly familiar with how x86 backend does **'direct'** NCHW[8,16]c convolution, including how kernel prepacking is done during precompute. But, here, I'm talking about filter transform for **'Wingrad'** convolution, which is totally different (it is not just reordering layout). 

I think kernel prepack is mainly for cpu backend. As long as you target x86, you can use 'llvm' target for precompute, and 'llvm -mcpu=skylake-avx512' for actual convolution. But Winograd filter transform is relevant for both cpu and gpu. I cannot use gpu specific winograd filter transform with 'llvm' target.
